Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: The nursing assistant is on their morning rounds to help a patient with their daily routine.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
I walked briskly down the hallway, clipboard in hand, ready to help Mrs. Evans with her morning routine. As a nursing assistant, I knew how much she depended on me for her bath and breakfast, especially since her arthritis had flared up again. The hospital was short-staffed today, and I could already hear the call bells ringing from other rooms. My supervisor expected me to be quick and efficient, but I also wanted to give each patient the care and attention they deserved.

As I entered Mrs. Evans’ room, my phone buzzed with a reminder: Sunday worship at church was starting soon. I hadn’t been able to attend in weeks, and I missed the sense of peace and community it brought me. My faith was important, and I felt a responsibility to be present, to worship, and to support my church family. But here I was, needed just as much in this hospital, with patients relying on me for their most basic needs.

I stood at the foot of Mrs. Evans’ bed, torn between my duty to my patients and my longing to be at church, wrestling with the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
